CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: If working closely with Muslim nations and the American Muslim community is crucial for obtaining intelligence on terrorism, then does ignoring and alienating them through divisive rhetoric not undermine our national security efforts?

Do you have a scientific study or credible evidence that suggests that working closely with the American Muslim community would significantly increase the amount of intelligence gathered on terrorism?
If Americans are expected to have a strong alliance with countries in Europe and the Middle East, why should American Muslims not be considered allies in the fight against terrorism?
If we need to work closely with Muslim nations to gather intelligence, why did Donald Trump's rhetoric alienate the American Muslim community?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: If the wealthy pay their fair share and corporate loopholes are closed, do you think it will actually lead to affordable child care and debt-free college as promised?
Do you have a credible economic source that supports the claim that increasing taxes on the wealthy will be sufficient to fund paid family leave, earned sick days, and debt-free college?
If corporate executives are seen as deserving of profits, why should they not also be held accountable for the benefits that come from them?
If you're pushing for the wealthy to pay their fair share, then shouldn't you also ensure that the middle class benefits directly from their contributions?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: Will reverting to the economic policies that failed in the past lead to another economic downturn and exacerbate the suffering of those who were already impacted?

Do independent experts have factually evaluated and verified the effectiveness of your clean energy plan and the feasibility of the United States becoming the clean-energy superpower of the 21st century?
If a country can recover from a massive economic downfall like the one we experienced, why would it be impossible for individuals to recover from losing their homes and livelihoods?
If the economic recovery was truly a success, then why are we still using the same policies that led to the devastating losses in the first place?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: What effect would invoking Article 5 have had on the international community's stance on Iran if the US had not intervened in the situation during Clinton's time as Secretary of State?
Do you have a scientific source that confirms Iran was actually weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb when you became Secretary of State?
If the US would come to the aid of a NATO member state threatened by terrorism, why would it not do the same for a non-member state threatened by terrorism?
If Clinton's administration successfully prevented Iran from developing nuclear weapons, why did we not apply a similar strategy with North Korea, which poses a similar threat?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's past diplomatic successes with Iran demonstrate a consistent approach to conflict resolution that would be effective in addressing current global challenges?
Can you provide evidence that shows the sanctions you supported were more effective than the deal your successor, John Kerry, and President Obama negotiated?
If Clinton's diplomatic efforts with Iran were deemed successful, why is her handling of the situation with the Benghazi attack considered a failure?
If diplomacy was so effective with Iran, why did it take a threat of military action by North Korea to bring them to the negotiating table?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: Does taunting or critical behavior from a potential commander-in-chief lead to poor decision-making and a lack of effective leadership?
Do you have any scholarly research or evidence to support the claim that being "taunted" is an essential qualification for the commander-in-chief?

If being taunted is a disqualifying characteristic for a potential commander-in-chief, why did past leaders like Harry Truman and Lyndon B. Johnson, who were also frequently criticized and mocked, succeed in their roles?
If temperament is a requirement for being a commander-in-chief, then is it fair to hold Bill Clinton to a different standard than other leaders who have been taunted?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: If his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is deeply troubling, what preventative measures or actions would he take to address this issue?
Does the President's stance on nuclear weapons align with the views of nuclear experts and international leaders, considering his description as the "number-one threat" to the world?

If a nuclear weapon is considered the greatest threat to global security, why is not addressing climate change, which is estimated to cause millions of deaths annually, not considered a similarly pressing issue?
If nuclear weapons are the number-one threat we face in the world, then shouldn't we take a more serious stance against all countries that pose a threat with them, rather than just terrorists?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: Does this description of the problem being discussed accurately represent the issue that will cause significant consequences for the people involved?
Can you provide a credible source to support your claim that this 'problem' is accurately described?

If society accepts that a first-generation American's experiences and opportunities are significantly influenced by their parents' immigration status, then wouldn't a second-generation American's experiences and opportunities be similarly shaped by their parents' historical experiences?
If it so accurately describes the problem, then what specific actions will you take to address it?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: If his proposed deal with Iran has been successful in giving us access to facilities we never had before, then why does he criticize it?
Can you provide evidence from scientific studies that support the claim that people around the world can reliably infer your policy positions from your campaign rhetoric?
If Clinton's intention is to lead the world with strength and in accordance with values, would her actions not be more effective if she were to provide a clear and transparent plan to defeat ISIS?
If the deal with Iran has been so successful, why should we not have faith in your alternative plan to defeat ISIS?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: Will deploying a half a billion more solar panels create enough jobs to outweigh the negative economic effects of the environmental regulations that will be implemented to support this initiative?
What is the scientific evidence that supports your claim that deploying half a billion solar panels and building a new modern electric grid would create a significant amount of new economic activity?

If deploying a half a billion solar panels and building a new electric grid is a viable solution to boost the economy, why isn't investing in renewable energy a more comprehensive answer to addressing our energy needs rather than just a temporary stimulus?
If you're determined to move the economy forward, shouldn't you focus on more than just renewable energy projects and create a comprehensive plan addressing the root causes of the economic issues?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: If enforcing trade deals and increasing exports results in a 30-50% increase in American exports, why does this not guarantee a similar boost in job creation?
Can you provide evidence from your time as secretary of state that demonstrates a 30 percent increase in American exports globally?
If Clinton increased American exports by 30 percent during her time as secretary of state, would she be able to replicate this success in the current economic climate?
If you increased exports to China by 50 percent as Secretary of State, does that justify voting against CAFTA, a deal that could potentially lead to more trade and job opportunities in the US?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: Does having experience as a senator and secretary of state inherently qualify one to be a more effective president?
Can you provide evidence from your time as secretary of state to support your claim that you've "done a lot"?
If being a senator and secretary of state are seen as comparable positions, would that imply that one's experience in each is equivalent?
If you have done a lot as secretary of state, then why is your opponent's lack of experience a valid reason to disqualify him from the presidency?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: Will prioritizing new jobs and investments over tax cuts lead to a more stable economy and rising incomes.
Can you provide evidence from reputable economic sources that supports your assertion that investments, rather than tax cuts, are the most effective way to stimulate the economy?
If we consider the economic policies of Clinton as a cure-all for America's economic issues, would that not be akin to treating a patient with a single pill when they have a complex illness?
If we're prioritizing economic growth over other concerns, then aren't we inadvertently fostering an environment where wealth accumulation is valued over human well-being?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: If your plan is so robust as you claim, why does independent analysis suggest it would lead to a loss of 3.5 million jobs and a recession?
Can you provide a detailed breakdown of how your "Stronger Together" plan would create 10 million jobs, considering the economic models and data that support this claim?

If economic plans can be evaluated based on their job-creating potential, why is it that a plan with a higher job-creation rate, such as hers, is seen as more viable than one with a lower job-creation rate?
If you claim your plan would create jobs, why does it project a recession and job losses?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: Will the proposed tax increase on the wealthy lead to a significant reduction in their investment in small businesses, thus offsetting the potential economic benefits of the deregulation policies?
Can you provide empirical evidence to support the claim that raising taxes on the wealthy would not disproportionately harm small businesses and the economy?
If the wealthy and corporations are expected to contribute more to the country's financial needs, why is it unreasonable to ask second-generation immigrants to pay their fair share as well?
If what you propose would not add a penny to the debt, then why do your opponents' plans add $5 trillion, and what does that say about the effectiveness of your financial management?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: Would a tax system that rewards financial transactions over work lead to economic growth or exacerbate income inequality?

Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that a tax system rewarding work over financial transactions is more effective in growing the economy than one focused on financial transactions?
If a 2nd generation American from a wealthy family inherits wealth and privilege, why should a 2nd generation American from a lower-income family not have similar benefits?
If rewarding work over financial transactions is a key aspect of a fair tax system, why does Clinton's proposed tax system prioritize investment over work?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's experience growing up in a small-business family, where he saw firsthand the struggles of entrepreneurship, influence his stance on supporting the middle class over the wealthy?

Does your experience with your father's small business support the notion that wealth is primarily achieved through individual effort, or do you believe that a more collective approach to economic growth benefits society as a whole?
If one's success is largely attributed to family wealth and privilege, is it fair to suggest that others can achieve similar success through hard work and determination alone?
If his father's wealth was the key to his success, then why does he think the middle class, without such a wealthy advantage, can achieve the same level of prosperity?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: If the proposed tax changes do not incentivize companies to repatriate their foreign earnings, what alternative measures would be effective in bringing back the stranded money?
Does any reputable economic study confirm that reducing corporate tax rates would indeed lead to repatriation of money that is stranded overseas?

If corporations can benefit from tax breaks after being in the United States for two generations, why would that not be seen as justification for offering similar benefits to long-established American families of non-corporate entities?
If Clinton supports bringing back money that's stranded overseas, then why doesn't she support the tax proposals that would actually facilitate that?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: Does the proposed policy contain a loophole that would benefit the business interests of the speaker, thus causing them to gain an unfair advantage?
Can you provide a scientific source that supports the claim that women benefit more from a specific policy or law than men?
If a tax benefit is seen as a loophole when it disproportionately advantages one group, why wouldn't a similar benefit be considered a privilege when it advantages another?
If your proposal is supposed to benefit us, then why does it seem to benefit you more than the country?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: Does slashing taxes on the wealthy actually stimulate economic growth, or does it disproportionately benefit the wealthy at the expense of the middle class?
Can you provide empirical evidence from peer-reviewed studies that supports your assertion that broad-based, inclusive growth is more effective in boosting the economy than trickle-down economics?
If trickle-down economics has failed to boost the economy, why would broad-based, inclusive growth through tax cuts for the wealthy be expected to achieve the same outcome?
If Clinton's economic policies are effective at boosting the economy, why did her own economic policies in the 1990s not lead to more equitable growth and a stronger middle class?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: Does suppressing moral hazard in lending and borrowing processes actually lead to the creation of more "real" wealth rather than just "fool's gold"?
Can you provide a study or evidence from a reputable economist or financial expert that supports your claim that ignoring moral hazard in lending and borrowing leads to fool's gold?
If ignoring moral hazard in lending leads to fake wealth, why is ignoring moral hazard in hiring and education not similarly seen as a problem?
If ignoring moral hazard leads to fool’s gold, shouldn’t we prioritize addressing its root causes rather than merely suppressing its symptoms?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Will restricting peanut products on airlines actually lead to a significant reduction in life-threatening reactions among passengers?
Can you provide evidence from reputable medical literature to support your claim that restricting peanut products on airlines is the most effective solution for preventing life-threatening reactions?

If a physician-mom's personal experience and online support group justify a blanket ban on peanuts in all airline settings, why wouldn't a doctor's personal experience and online support group justify a blanket ban on peanuts in all public places?

If peanut products are so inherently hazardous, shouldn't airlines, which are already required to accommodate various medical conditions, take a more comprehensive approach to protecting passengers with peanut allergies?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: Does the increased hostility and unlikability of the Republican candidates during the debates actually contribute to a decreased likelihood of their nominee winning the general election?
Can you name one moment during the debate that you found acceptable or constructive, as that would help clarify your claim that the entire panel seems unlikable?
If listening to a heated argument between two family members can evoke a sense of unlikability and alienation, would this not be a fitting analogy to describe the current state of the GOP debates?
If the current debate format is indeed making the entire panel unlikable, doesn't that imply that the GOP's approach is more likely to alienate voters rather than persuade them?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: If exposure to airborne peanut particles can cause a severe allergic reaction, does that mean that airline travel will become an unviable option for individuals with severe peanut allergies, forcing them to choose between their career aspirations and their health?
Can you provide scientific evidence that supports the classification of food allergies as disabilities, thereby warranting the same accommodations and protections as physical disabilities?

If being severely allergic to peanuts renders a child unable to travel by plane, wouldn't that be analogous to being born into a family of a different socioeconomic status rendering a child unable to attend a private school?
If a child with a life-threatening food allergy is barred from experiencing the world, should their parents also be barred from experiencing the world through international travel?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: Does banning peanuts from flights effectively cause an undue burden on airline passengers, outweighing the benefits of accommodating peanut allergy sufferers?

Does your personal experience with a medical condition justify imposing restrictions on others, such as eating peanuts on a flight, despite allergy sufferers having alternative solutions like seat separation and individual protective measures?
If people with peanut allergies are expected to take precautions to minimize their exposure to peanuts, why should frequent-flyers not be expected to take similar precautions to accommodate them?

If passengers with peanut allergies are expected to take precautions to minimize their risk while flying, why should they not be expected to take similar precautions on the ground, rather than expecting others to compromise their own freedoms?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: If an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US, then what alternative gun control measures would actually have a significant impact?
Do you have any scientific studies or evidence to support the claim that an assault weapons ban is ineffective in addressing homicide rates in the US?
If the DOJ's findings on an assault weapons ban are to be considered sound, then why is Bernie's stance on reinstating it seen as illogical?
If the DOJ determined that an assault weapons ban won't address homicide rates, then what alternative gun control measures would be effective in reducing gun violence?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: Does the ruling against stop-and-frisk policies in New York effectively reduce racial profiling and mitigate its disparate impact on communities of color?

Can you provide a scholarly study that supports your claim that the Stop-and-frisk policy disproportionately targeted black and Hispanic young men, rather than simply acknowledging it as a fact based on court rulings?

If stop-and-frisk policies can be deemed unconstitutional for targeting specific ethnic groups, why wouldn't policies that disproportionately affect certain racial groups in the job market or education system also be deemed unconstitutional?

If stop-and-frisk was deemed unconstitutional for targeting a specific demographic, should the police department's similar profiling of black and Hispanic communities be viewed as any less problematic?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: Does the consideration of changing the policy on first use of nuclear weapons lead to a decrease in global tensions and an increase in international cooperation?

Does any credible scientific study support the notion that President Obama considered changing the nation's policy on first use of nuclear weapons, and if so, what were the conclusions of such a study?

If nuclear weapons are considered a necessary evil for national security, why would it be considered acceptable for the US to be the first to use them, while other nations are held to a different standard?
If President Obama considered changing the policy on first use of nuclear weapons, does that imply that the current policy is ineffective in securing America?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money to—who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: If a presidential candidate's financial records reveal significant conflicts of interest, does that necessarily mean they will prioritize their personal gain over the interests of the American people?
Does the public's right to transparency and accountability in a president's financial dealings supersede the personal right to privacy?
If a presidential candidate's tax returns have been a standard expectation for decades, why should that not be expected of all public officials?

If transparency is a key aspect of accountability, why should the public be denied access to a presidential candidate's tax returns when it is a standard practice for transparency in American politics?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: Would intervening in families who need a great deal of help actually cause them to become less reliant on support and more self-sufficient, or would it perpetuate a cycle of dependency?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports your claim that some families are capable of receiving sufficient help and support to become effective parents?
If we intervene to help families in need, why wouldn't we also provide support to families with high levels of aggression and violence, rather than simply labelling them as a problem to be managed?
If some families are in need of help and intervention, why do others who are terrorising communities not receive the same assistance?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it
republicans used to get mocked and laughed at when they said that illegal immigrants would be getting obamacare coverage"

cqs.cq: Does the availability of healthcare coverage to undocumented immigrants cause an increase in their presence and participation in society?

Can you provide a scientific study or credible source that supports the claim that undocumented immigrants should be granted the same rights and benefits as citizens, and if so, how does it address the concerns of national sovereignty and public welfare?

If American citizens who were born and raised here, but have ancestors who were not initially lawfully present, are entitled to benefits, why would immigrants who meet the same criteria and contribute to society be denied the same benefits?
If they are indeed a part of this society, as you claim, then shouldn't they also have access to the same rights and benefits as every other citizen?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: If implementing a maximum tarmac delay trigger would cause airlines to prioritize efficiency over passenger comfort, would this ultimately lead to increased stress-related health issues among travelers?
Do you have any military or aviation expert opinion that supports deplaning passengers without CBP screening as a viable and safe alternative to tarmac delays?
If a military member has the ability to deplane during gate holds without penalty, why should commercial airline passengers not be given the same option?

If deplaning during a tarmac delay is allowed for military personnel during overseas contract flights, why should it not be made available to all passengers as a compromise measure to alleviate frustrations during excessive delays?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: If seat size and configuration are deemed a health issue, why shouldn't the lack of leg room and arm space be considered a cause of potential illness and injury to passengers?

Can you provide a credible medical study that supports the claim that seat size and configuration pose a significant health risk to passengers, warranting government intervention to regulate airline seating?
If seat size and configuration are considered a health issue, why aren't extra legroom options viewed as a health necessity, rather than an expensive luxury?

If airlines are forced to address seat size and configuration as a health issue, why can they not be held accountable for the health implications of charging exorbitant fees for carrying pets onboard?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: Does the risk of anaphylaxis from peanut exposure on airplanes pose a significant enough threat to justify a ban on peanut and tree nut products from flights?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the risk of anaphylaxis from peanut exposure on airplanes warrants a complete ban on peanut and tree nut products from flights?

If a life-threatening allergy is seen as a legitimate reason to ban certain items from airplanes, would other potentially deadly health conditions, such as heart conditions, also warrant similar exemptions?

If the risk of severe allergic reactions on airplanes is so high, then why should other potentially deadly items, like sharp objects or hazardous chemicals, be permitted on flights if they pose a similar risk to passengers?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: If a candidate is unable to discuss the details of their plan due to the constraints of a timed response, does that inherently undermine the effectiveness of their communication with voters?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports the claim that politicians are less likely to have a comprehensive plan compared to other professions?

If a politician's lack of transparency in a debate is seen as a shocking moment in American history, would the public's expectation of politicians to provide detailed plans in their responses be seen as outdated?
If his plan is all there, why can't he talk about everything in it?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: Does the airline industry's reliance on self-monitoring lead to inadequate customer service and potentially life-threatening consequences for passengers with allergies?
Do you have any empirical evidence from the airline industry that suggests their self-regulation is effective in maintaining the quality of customer service and minimizing risks to passengers?
If airlines are left to self-monitor and provide potentially inaccurate or incomplete information, would this not be analogous to leaving children unsupervised in a playground?
If the airline industry is allowed to self-monitor, don't we risk exposing passengers to severe psychological distress and potentially life-threatening situations?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: If the current emphasis on minority interests and needs leads to such a polarized atmosphere, does it ultimately cause more harm than good in the pursuit of finding a compromise position?

Can you provide evidence that demonstrates the scientific consensus among medical associations, including the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, supports the claim that accommodations for transgender individuals are a proven necessity?

If the majority of Americans can opt out of a mandate to purchase health insurance for themselves and their families, why should they not also be able to opt out of a mandate to respect the rights and needs of minority groups?
If they have access to the studies and still hold a prejudgment against the researchers, doesn't that undermine the credibility of their criticism?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: If peanut allergens can indeed be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners, do you think airlines should be required to implement more stringent air filtration systems to minimize the risk of peanut allergens being present in the air onboard?
Can you provide a scientific study that confirms that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings, as you claim?

If a child's peanut allergy can be safely managed through desensitization, would it not be equally reasonable to accommodate peanut-allergic passengers on flights by implementing measures to minimize exposure to peanut allergens?

If air onboard an airliner is indeed cleaner than in most public buildings, as you claim, why is it unreasonable to assume that passengers with peanut allergies could still be exposed to peanut allergens through recirculated air?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Does the prevalence of peanut allergies among the general population justify the widespread restriction of peanuts on airplanes?
Do you have a medical study that supports your claim that peanuts are more nutritious than other foods, pound for pound?
If the consumption of peanuts on airplanes poses a negligible risk to most people, why should they be banned for the sake of a tiny fraction of the population?
Are peanuts being served on airplanes more of a source of comfort and enjoyment for the majority, or a threat to the minority with a legitimate allergy?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: Would changing the pricing strategy of your retail business to match the dynamic pricing used by airlines lead to increased customer distrust and a negative impact on your business reputation?

Do you have any scientific evidence or studies that support the claim that consumers would never return to a business that frequently changes prices or engages in bait-and-switch tactics, as you assert?
If airlines are allowed to charge exorbitant fees under the guise of taxes, would it be just to allow retail businesses to similarly inflate their prices through deceitful pricing practices?
If airlines are allowed to charge such high taxes as a separate item, isn't that essentially the same as a retail store baiting customers with a low price and then switching to a higher priced item?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: If the wealthy fail to invest productively and instead prioritize consumer credit, do you think it exacerbates the economic disparities that lead to social progress?
Can you provide a scientific study or credible source that supports the claim that the wealthy have a higher propensity for social progress than the poor?

If wealthy individuals have historically been the primary drivers of social progress, why would their financial institutions be expected to solely focus on providing consumer credit rather than taking calculated risks to benefit society?
If the wealthy are capable of making productive investments, why have they instead focused on providing consumer credit?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: Does a culture of credit-based consumerism, as described, contribute to the financial instability that manifests in widespread economic downturns?
Can you provide a scientific source that supports the claim that people who took sub-prime mortgages were the primary beneficiaries of a policy?
If those who benefited from sub-prime mortgages were not held accountable, why should we expect those who benefited from systemic racism and colonialism to be held accountable?

If your criticism of the policy is that it primarily benefited those who took the sub-prime mortgages, then why would you not apply the same standard to other policies that have devastating consequences?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: If Clinton's tax returns are being used as a model for transparency, then why should voters hold Trump to a different standard regarding his tax returns?
Do you have a credible source that supports the claim that the IRS has explicitly stated there is no prohibition on releasing tax returns when under audit?
If transparency in tax returns is a standard expectation for a presidential candidate, why is it not applied to all candidates, including the current one?
If Mr. Trump's tax returns are so transparent, then why did he only release a couple of years' worth, and not the 40 years of tax returns that his opponent has made available?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: If race continues to determine where people live and the quality of education they receive, can we truly expect to restore trust between communities and the police?
Do you have a study or data that supports the claim that race still determines too much in our country?
If race still determines where people live, what education they receive, and how they're treated in the criminal justice system, would it not perpetuate systemic inequalities?
If race still determines too much in America, why can't we acknowledge and address systemic inequalities in the justice system as a first step towards reform?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: Will implementing her proposed criminal justice reforms be sufficient to restore trust between law enforcement and communities, or will they be overshadowed by the continued presence of guns in the wrong hands?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that young African-American men are more frequently victims of gun violence than any other demographic?

If the US acknowledges the historical injustices faced by African-American communities as a reason for current disparities, would that not imply a need for similar consideration and reparations for other historically marginalized groups?
If restoring trust and improving policing is a top priority, why does your plan not address the systemic issues within law enforcement agencies that have led to the mistrust in the first place?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's assertion that she believes in community policing, while citing crime statistics, effectively address the root causes of the problems she is trying to solve?
Do you have any evidence from scientific studies that supports the claim that community policing is more effective than stop-and-frisk policies in reducing crime rates?

If Stop-and-frisk was deemed unconstitutional due to its ineffectiveness, would implementing a similar community policing policy that disproportionately targets black and Latino communities not also be unconstitutional?
If stop-and-frisk was deemed unconstitutional and ineffective in reducing crime, how can we justify implementing policies that mirror its principles?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: Does the existence of systemic racism in the criminal justice system cause a disproportionate number of young African-American men to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports your claim that mandatory minimum sentences have put too many people away for too long for doing too little?

If the system disproportionately targets and punishes young African-American men, why wouldn't it also disproportionately target and punish other groups that are perceived as a threat to societal norms and expectations?
If we're acknowledging that systemic racism exists within the criminal justice system, why are you, a former prosecutor, implying that the system is not inherently flawed?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: If New York's approach to community policing has been effective in reducing crime, then why should other cities not adopt similar strategies to address their own crime problems?
Does any research support the claim that the community-led approach to reducing crime in New York has been effective in other communities?

If New York has achieved a significant reduction in crime through collaboration between the community, faith groups, businesses, and law enforcement, why should other cities not attempt similar approaches to address their own crime issues?
If New York has done such an excellent job in reducing killings, then why are we not implementing its strategies in other communities?

CLINTON_17.input:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: Does a tax policy that primarily benefits the wealthy and neglects the middle class create a perfect storm that can lead to economic crises like the Great Recession?
Can you provide a credible source that supports the claim that Donald Trump was one of the people who actively rooted for the housing crisis?
If the economic policies of the past were responsible for the Great Recession, would the current economic policies of the present not be similarly responsible for the current financial struggles?
If Clinton's policies were responsible for the Great Recession, why are we now implementing policies that mirror those she criticized?

CLINTON_176_1.input:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: If Russia's cyber attacks on the US have been successful, can we expect a corresponding increase in the number of Russian operatives embedded within the US government and private sectors?
Do you have evidence that Russia has been directly linked to all instances of cyber attacks mentioned by Clinton, or are they merely suspected?
If the US government acknowledges Russia's cyber attacks as a threat, why would it not acknowledge the hacking groups from other countries or independent hackers as a similar threat?
If you're praising Putin's strategic thinking, does that justify ignoring his country's cyber aggression against the US?

CLINTON_176_2.input:
CLINTON: "we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information
We need to make it very clear—whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else—the United States has much greater capacity
we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information
 we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have
We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare
we will defend the citizens of this country
 the Russians need to understand that
 they've been treating it as almost a probing, how far would we go, how much would we do
I was so shocked when Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans
That is just unacceptable"

cqs.cq: Will engaging in a cyber war with foreign actors actually prevent them from trying to collect information on American citizens?
Can you provide evidence that the Russian government has been "probing" US cybersecurity defenses, as you claimed, or is that simply a hypothetical scenario?
If Russia's actions are considered unacceptable, why should the US not take similar measures to defend its citizens from hackers, just as it expects other nations to defend theirs?
If we're not going to engage in a different kind of warfare, then why do we have the capacity to respond with cyber warfare measures against other nations?

CLINTON_186.input:
CLINTON: "there are a number of issues that we should be addressing
I have put forth a plan to defeat ISIS
It does involve going after them online
we need to do much more with our tech companies to prevent ISIS and their operatives from being able to use the Internet to radicalize , even direct people in our country and Europe and elsewhere
eventually support our Arab and Kurdish partners to be able to actually take out ISIS in Raqqa
end their claim of being a Caliphate
We 're making progress
Our military is assisting in Iraq
we 're hoping that within the year we 'll be able to push ISIS out of Iraq
really squeeze them in Syria
we have to be cognizant of the fact that they 've had foreign fighters coming to volunteer for them
foreign money
foreign weapons
we have to make this the top priority
I would also do everything possible to take out their leadership
I was involved in a number of efforts to take out Al Qaida leadership when I was secretary of state
including , of course , taking out bin Laden
we need to go after Baghdadi , as well
make that one of our organizing principles
we 've got to defeat ISIS
we 've got to do everything we can to disrupt their propaganda efforts online"

cqs.cq: If going after ISIS online involves working with tech companies to prevent radicalization, does this approach effectively address the root causes of radicalization, or does it merely treat its symptoms?
Do you have a scientific study or credible source that supports the claim that ISIS can be defeated solely through online efforts, or is this a purely anecdotal or anecdotal approach?
If fighting a terrorist organization's online presence is a priority, why wouldn't addressing systemic online hate groups in the US also be a priority?

aimwill_178.input:
aimwill: "Perhaps i am missing something here
If airlines are selling the seats for full price and people don't show up for the flight, doesn't the airline still pocket that money?
And with the hubbub about the extra weight of luggage, wouldn't having a few empty seats DECREASE the cost of the flight by increasing fuel efficiency?
Like I said, I may be missing a key detail, but it really does seem like the airlines are gambling that people won't show up and they can get paid twice for the same seat.
If the airlines are refunding people based on them missing flights, perhaps stopping THAT practice and disallowing overbooking would solve the problem??
If someone is really worried about missing their flight and being compensated, they can buy trip insurance.
The rest of us won't have to worry about getting bumped.
I think so :)"

cqs.cq: If the airlines are selling seats at full price but not guaranteeing their availability, does this practice effectively turn into a form of price gouging?
Can you provide evidence from airline industry reports or studies that support your claim that airlines are deliberately overbooking flights knowing that some passengers will miss their flights?
If airlines are pocketing money from unsold seats, why wouldn't they simply absorb the cost of empty seats rather than overbooking flights?
If airlines are indeed pocketing money from unclaimed seats, why would they still engage in the practice of overbooking when it creates unnecessary inconvenience for passengers?

ambersky_145.input:
ambersky: "I agree with chartley81.
My child has a right to live.
What about the fact that other things have been banned on airlines
I think you can survive not eating peanuts for a few hours,
but my son may not survive the flight if you decide to touch the armrest with a peanut oil covered hand and then he touches it.
yes there are always risks
but banning it lessens that risk to an extent."

cqs.cq: Does banning peanuts on airlines significantly reduce the risk of anaphylaxis in children, thereby justifying the restriction?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that a child's life would be at significant risk from exposure to peanut oil on an armrest, to justify banning peanuts on airlines?
If banning peanuts on flights significantly reduces the risk of anaphylaxis, would similarly prohibiting the presence of certain foods in schools lessen the risk of food allergies in children?
If a child's life can be at risk from a peanut allergy, why should the airline industry not prioritize passenger safety by banning peanut products onboard flights?

annoyed_177.input:
annoyed: "Is there any formula that says how much airlines can overbook?
Should it be proportional to number of seats available?
Also, what about bumping according to when the ticket was purchased?
I plan well ahead of time and resent being bumped since I may have paid less.
Zero fare passengers should most certainly be compensated in some way."
 < this message is answering to > 
citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,
But to assure adequate compensation and prevent airlines gaming such a requirement,
compensation should be at the average (cash) ticket price for that service class on that flight.
DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would encourage airlines to bump those with zeroprice tickets first,
since that cost would be lowest.
As long as they continue to offer tickets for miles, airlines should not be encouraged to treat passengers using those tickets as secondclass when it comes to bumping.
The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
something that cries out for regulatory intervention
is bad enough."

cqs.cq: If the airline's current overbooking policies cause passengers to be involuntarily bumped, then do you think requiring airlines to compensate bumped passengers based on the average ticket price for that service class would effectively prevent them from gaming such a system?
Do you have a scientific study or data to support the claim that passengers with zero-price tickets should be prioritized for compensation over those who paid more for their tickets?
If airlines are allowed to overbook and bump passengers based on their ticket price, wouldn't that resemble a system where people are punished for being thrifty and planning ahead?

If airlines are allowed to overbook in a way that disproportionately affects passengers with zero-fare tickets, doesn't that create a form of price discrimination against those who do not pay for their tickets?

atraveller_82_1.input:
atraveller: "Although we always travel with epipens in case our fiveryearold peanut & tree nut allergic child needs them,
I think having some on board is a good idea,
as long as crew are trained in the proper usage.
Moreover, I think the crew need training on how to respectfully treat people with allergies or disabilities.
Since our son was diagnosed with the allergy one year ago, we have travelled several times on multiple carriers and have found the foreign carriers to be far less worrisome for those with nut allergies.
In fact, none of the foreign carriers we used during that time even served nuts in economy."

cqs.cq: Does the fact that foreign carriers have been found to be less worrisome for those with nut allergies indicate that stricter allergy protocols are not necessary on domestic flights?

Can you provide evidence from a reputable airline that shows their crew members have received training on both the use of epipens and the respectful treatment of passengers with allergies and disabilities?
If foreign carriers are more accommodating to travellers with allergies, why should domestic airlines not take similar steps to ensure passenger safety?
If foreign carriers can accommodate nut allergies more effectively, why can't domestic airlines prioritize allergy safety measures and training for crew members?

atraveller_82_2.input:
atraveller: "Our only trouble came with Delta.
On flights to and from Atlanta to El Salvador, I requested a nutfree buffer zone as listed as an option on the Delta website.
This request was not observed on either flight,
and I when mentioned it to the cabin crew on one segment, they began taking back the nuts from the passengers around us, pointing out that they couldn't have it because "that little boy is allergic."
This made us very uncomfortable, but at least the other passengers were polite about it.
