The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: Would requiring airlines to provide compensation for passengers if the aircraft remains on the ground for more than 3 hours cause a significant increase in the number of passengers choosing to deplane during gate holds?
Can you provide evidence from a scientific study that supports the claim that deplaning without CBP screening is a viable and safe option during extended gate holds?
If military members can deplane during overseas contract flights without compromising security, why would civilian passengers not be allowed the same option during prolonged gate holds?
If crew members are not paid while sitting at a gate, is it unreasonable to expect passengers to wait for up to three hours, or should they be allowed to deplane and remain in the immediate area?

golff4fun_162.input:
golff4fun: "Since weight seems to be the issue with charging extra fees for checked luggage,
the 98 lb person should pay less for a ticket than the 250 pounder.
I have thought that from the very beginning when the airlines introduced this new fee."
 < this message is answering to > 
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: If airlines are allowed to charge extra fees based on weight, wouldn't this lead to a significant increase in weight-related anxiety among passengers?
Is there any scientific evidence that supports the notion that airline companies can discriminate against passengers based on weight without violating existing regulations?

If airlines can charge extra fees based on a passenger's weight, would they also be justified in charging extra fees based on other physical characteristics, such as height, body mass index, or muscle mass?
If weight-based pricing is used for checked luggage, why should it not be applied to other airline services, such as seat selection or legroom, to ensure fairness among all passengers?

grayk47__302.input:
grayk47: " you give an illegally (as in you stole it) acquired firearm to a friend to use responsibly
that person accidentally shoots someone
who should be blamed
Both should be held responsible
This is the same case for Snowden
he gave illegally acquired papers that he stole, to the Times in the hopes that they would responsible with it
They failed in that
a terrorist group was able to use the exposed information to alter their plans
It's cut and dry"

cqs.cq: If the person who gave the illegally acquired firearm to their friend had been aware of the risk of irresponsible use, would they still have made the same decision?
Do you consider the distinction between handing over classified information and a stolen firearm to be a morally or legally significant difference in terms of responsibility?
If one is held accountable for the misuse of a stolen firearm, why should Snowden not be held accountable for the misuse of stolen documents?

If the person who gave you an illegally acquired firearm to use responsibly is held accountable for the consequences of its misuse, why should the person who leaked classified information for the purpose of responsible disclosure be treated differently?

hgranato_211.input:
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: Would implementing a blanket ban on peanuts on flights and in airport restaurants cause more problems than it solves due to the impracticality of enforcement and the potential for unintended consequences?
Do you have a scientific study that confirms the likelihood of a serious reaction from tree nuts is significantly lower than from peanuts?
If airlines require passengers to provide advance notice of medical conditions, why should they not also require passengers with severe allergies to take proactive steps to mitigate risks?
If severe reactions from tree nuts are similar to those from peanuts, why should airlines implement special precautions for one but not the other?

howie_201.input:
howie: "First, stop reading that propaganda magazine.
Publications like that only serve to create fear in minds like yours.
Second, how old is your kid?
If under 5, relax the sensitivity will probably go away by the time he is 5.
Third, go to a real doctor  not an allergist and see if there is really even a problem at all.
This supposed plague of food allergies is the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists.
Allergists are not doctors.
I sincerely doubt you "know plenty of people who will die if they do have peanuts or breathe in peanut dust".
Almost noone is actually that allergic.
Lot's of people think they are much worse off than they really are.
Methinks you have an agenda.
Highly suspicious that the child of a physician who is hyper aware of bad things that can happen coincidentally has not one, but three life threatening allergies.
Have you heard of Munchasen by Proxy?
Do you realize that most kids have mild reactions to various food items that they invariably grow out of by the age of 5?
Food allergies have to be the most overblown imagined health problem of our time.
Hypochondriacs all."
 < this message is answering to > 
jsooudi: "I'm a physician, epidemiologist, and mother to a four year old boy with allergies to milk, peanuts and egg.
My son's dairy allergy is severe,
and he has had numerous lifethreatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk,
which required multiple doses of epinephrine and trips to the Emergency Department.
Tests indicate that his peanut allergy is worse,
but fortunately he has only been exposed once to a peanut;
he put one in his mouth and had a relatively mild  reaction.
I've traveled with my children
and despite calling ahead, making requests, and reminding employees at the door, I've rarely had respect, let alone consistency, in any kind of peanutfree buffer zone or flight.
Several years ago Continental Airlines customer service headquarters informed me that they would serve peanuts on all flights as they were unable to guarantee a peanut free flight.
(So why not hand out weapons since they can't guarantee a weapon free flight either?)
I've sat with my epi pen in hand on a filthy flight with visible peanut crumbs on the floor while a flight attendant insisted on offering peanuts to the passengers around me because "it was their right."
Fortunately for me, my son's peanut allergy is not severe enough that it prohibits us from air travel.
Now that he is old enough to not put things in his mouth, and to protect himself, we are safer.
However, I know of many, many others in the allergy community, children and adults who simply can NOT fly.
My son's dairy allergy is quite severe.
The world would be a much safer place for us if no one consumed milk near him.
If his skin touches anything that once touched milk, even if it was partially cleaned, he will get severe hives.
If he consumes even less than a drop, within seconds his lips, eyes and face will swell, he will be covered in hives, vomit, and be gasping for breath.
Without epinephrine he would probably die within minutes.
But milk is ubiquitous,
and milk allergy relatively uncommon,
so we must protect ourselves.
Peanut allergy is common,
and it is a simple step to serve an alternative peanut based snacks for a short period of time.
So why is this a big problem?
The vast majority of potential reactions would be eliminated by simply avoiding snacks that have peanuts or peanut butter as an ingredient.
Peanut oil is known to contain very little of the actual peanut protein,
and would be of little risk in an airborne environment.
As a physician, I have responded to the call from airline staff asking for emergency medical assistance.
I am well aware of how expensive and inconvenient it is to ground a plane.
In addition, most epipens come in two pack doses,
each of which are good for maybe 10 to 15 minutes.
Which in a severe anaphylactic reaction is simply not enough time between the beginning of a reaction and the patient reaching EMS.
I've found that other passengers, as a rule, are extremely supportive,
and are more than happy to help with a fellow passengers safety.
I think the people commenting on this site would react entirely differently were they seated next to an allergic child on a plane.
Of course they would refrain from eating peanuts for a few hours if they knew it would hurt someone they were looking in the face.
But I am sympathetic to individuals who are unhappy with yet another discomfort inflicted on air travelers.
This restriction is designed to protect people with allergies from the airlines callous disregard for cleanliness and for our safety, not from our fellow passengers.
"Hi.  My name is Steven.  I am 4 years old.
I am allergic to peanuts, eggs and cow milk.
If I eat a peanut I'll get sick.
I ate a nut one time and got a big bump on my lip and it swelled up and it was hard to breathe.
It was scary and my dad gave me some medicine that made it better.
I would like for them to not give out peanuts so I won't get sick because I'm allergic.
Everybody should drink Sprite and eat Pringles and Pretzels.""

cqs.cq: Does the airline's refusal to guarantee a peanut-free flight create a scenario that would cause your child's allergy to manifest and affect their safety while traveling?

Can you provide evidence from reputable medical journals that supports your claim that most children grow out of food allergies by the age of 5, given that your son's allergies are severe and have required multiple hospital visits?

If a 4-year-old child with a peanut allergy can experience life-threatening anaphylaxis from trace amounts of peanuts, why would a child's sensitivity to peanuts be expected to "probably go away" by the age of 5?
If you're a physician who's had to deal with life-threatening allergic reactions, then why do you think airlines can guarantee a peanut-free flight when even you acknowledge that it's impossible?

howie_208.input:
howie: "Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from eating peanuts?
Didn't think so.
Most food allergies are imagined.
You clearly have a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy.
If someone is actually that allergic, they should stay home and not inconvenience the rest of us."
 < this message is answering to > 
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Will restricting peanut products on airlines cause a significant increase in flight safety and prevent life-threatening allergic reactions?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports your claim that most food allergies are imagined, especially in the context of life-threatening peanut allergies?
If airline food is considered hazardous to the health of some individuals, why are cars, which are far more deadly, not banned on highways?
If you're so confident that peanut allergies are a minor issue, then why are you dismissing the potential life-threatening consequences that could occur from even the slightest exposure?

howie_213.input:
howie: "While I still dispute whether your reaction will be as severe as you believe, at least you realize that it is your responsibility to take precautions.
Your ailment is not shared by the general population,
and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."
 < this message is answering to > 
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: If your severe tree nut allergy causes you to experience a reaction, do you think the airline's inability to accommodate your needs would infringe upon your rights?

Do you think the airline industry should prioritize the rights of passengers with severe allergies over the general population, considering the impracticality and potential infringement on others' freedoms?

If airlines could have precautions in place for severe tree nut allergies, would they also need to have similar precautions for other less severe but still potentially life-threatening conditions, such as epilepsy or severe food poisoning?
If airlines can implement precautions to accommodate severe allergy sufferers, then shouldn't they also implement similar measures to accommodate those with other health issues, such as your ailment?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Does the perceived threat of peanuts on flights cause passengers with peanut allergies to have a significantly increased risk of anaphylaxis or other severe reactions?
Do you have a scientific study that supports your claim that most food allergies are completely imagined?
If most food allergies are indeed "completely imagined," why should a peanut allergy be treated with such caution and accommodations?
If the risk of death from a peanut allergy is extremely low, why are peanut bans on airlines still justified as a necessary safety measure?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: If peanut dust can cause life-threatening reactions in individuals with severe peanut allergies, why should airlines not be required to completely prohibit peanuts on flights to prevent such incidents?

Do you have any evidence that proves airline buffer zones would be effective in preventing life-threatening peanut dust reactions on flights, considering the air circulation systems and ventilation rates?
If flight attendants were allowed to smoke on board, would it be reasonable to expect passengers to inject themselves with nicotine-free saline to mitigate potential harm?
If peanut allergies are as severe as you claim, why do you think the implementation of a peanut-free zone on flights would be more difficult than the implementation of a smoke-free zone?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: Will banning peanuts on planes cause a significant increase in flight delays and financial losses for airlines?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that banning peanut products on planes would significantly reduce the risk of anaphylaxis among passengers with peanut allergies?

If peanut allergies pose a unique risk due to the potential for airborne particles, would allowing peanuts on planes be comparable to allowing other allergenic foods like shellfish or gluten, which also pose a risk of airborne particles?

If peanuts are the only food causing a unique risk of anaphylactic reactions due to their sticky nature and airborne particles, why not ban peanuts specifically, rather than implementing blanket policies to prohibit all nuts?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: Will airlines' focus on cost-cutting measures and profit maximization over passenger comfort lead to long-term consequences such as increased back and leg injuries among travelers?
Do you have any empirical evidence that supports your claim that airlines could save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design?

If airlines prioritize passenger comfort and space over profit, would that not lead to a more enjoyable and less grueling flying experience, thereby transforming air travel from a necessary evil to an eagerly anticipated experience?
If airlines are unwilling to provide adequate legroom and comfort in economy class, should they be expected to improve their overall service standards to justify the increasing costs of air travel?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: Does the airline's current pet travel policy cause a significant number of pet owners to forego traveling with their pets, thereby reducing airline revenue?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support your claim that your dog's behavior would be as good or better than some humans in the cabin?
If airlines allow service animals to travel in the cabin without restrictions, why would they not permit pets to do the same?
If airlines are willing to tolerate unruly human passengers, why should pet owners be forced to treat their well-behaved animals as cargo, incurring unnecessary costs and stress?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate
Chafee seemed like a trainwreck in the debate
O'Malley did alright
You might be right about his chances at getting the nomination
some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting
People were swearing up and down that Bernie didn't have a shot
no one had ever heard of him
Hillary was the only one getting airtime
now he's getting a lot of attention
 he's a competitive candidate
 I don't know a lot about O'Malley
nobody's been talking about him or interviewing him
I don't think he came off as a "sideshow" candidate in the debate
If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about"

cqs.cq: If O'Malley receives the same level of media coverage as the top Republican candidates, do you think he could surpass their polling numbers?
Do you have evidence from past elections that shows the amount of media coverage a candidate receives has a significant impact on their chances of nomination?

If a second-generation American with a different ethnicity can gain the same advantages as their parents, why would a second-generation American of European descent be considered less disadvantaged than a first-generation American of a different ethnicity?
If he's a competitive candidate, why has his media coverage been so limited in comparison to the Democrats?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: Will reducing the maximum flight delay from 3 hours to 2 hours lead to a significant decrease in passenger anxiety and stress related to flight delays?
Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that passengers' anxiety levels are significantly alleviated by receiving regular updates every 30 minutes, as you suggest?

If being subjected to long delays can cause significant stress for a white person with anxiety issues, why would it not be equally stressful for people of color who are already marginalized and disadvantaged?

If the primary purpose of this new rule is to alleviate passenger frustration, then should it also be applied to other forms of public transportation where passengers are often confined and delayed, such as buses and trains?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: Does the requirement for a news network to provide equal airtime to a Green Party candidate undermine the public's right to free speech by forcing a private entity to promote a viewpoint it disagrees with?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports the claim that a cable news network qualifies as a public place?

If a cable news network is considered a private entity, would it not set a precedent for restricting public discourse if it chooses not to give equal time to a presidential candidate from a smaller party?
If freedom of speech is a fundamental right, why should privately owned news networks be exempt from allowing a Green Party candidate to express their views on their platform?

secretcurse__139.input:
secretcurse: "The first debate was already limited to five people
According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: Do you think the large number of candidates will cause a diluted representation of the party's values and stances in the first debate.
Do you believe that a fair and representative first debate requires a more diverse and representative pool of candidates, rather than strictly adhering to the 5-person limit?
If the first debate was limited to five people, why would a similar limitation not be applied to the 171 candidates, making the selection process seem arbitrary and unfair?

If only five people are allowed to participate in the debate, does that not create an unfair advantage for a select few and disadvantage the remaining 166 candidates who have also filed the necessary paperwork?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: Will imposing stricter regulations on the airline industry result in better service to customers, or would it lead to higher costs and reduced airline competitiveness?

Do you have empirical evidence from reputable sources to support the claim that imposing common sense regulations on the airline industry would result in better service to customers without negatively impacting airline profits?
If commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom," would imposing regulations on the industry not be akin to establishing a minimum standard for a fair and safe competition among businesses?
If regulations are truly in the best interests of both airlines and passengers, then why would airlines have consistently opposed or circumvented them in the past?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: Does the potential negative health effects of prolonged sitting in commercial flights outweigh the inconvenience caused by deplaning and reboarding?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the deplaning and reboarding process outweighs the health risks associated with prolonged sitting on a commercial flight?
If airlines provide in-flight meals on certain flights, why wouldn't they also offer them on flights with prolonged ground delays?

If airlines prioritize passenger comfort and health, why should they restrict in-flight food and drink options to a bare minimum, potentially causing passengers to endure unnecessary discomfort and health risks?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: Will the delayed service of meals on a long flight, such as this one over the Atlantic, cause health problems for passengers who have limited time before their connecting flight?

Can you provide evidence from reputable medical or aviation studies that demonstrates the health risks associated with a delayed meal service on flights, particularly for passengers with specific dietary needs or restrictions?
If passengers can be held in a holding area without food or drink for an extended period, would that not be a form of in-flight detention?
If passengers can already be let out of the plane into a holding area without access to food and drink, why can't they be given food at the normal serving point if it's delayed?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: If an airline sells tickets at a lower price or allows passengers to redeem frequent flyer miles, would it not create a situation where passengers feel entitled to a seat on an overbooked flight and become upset if bumped?
Does your stance that airline tickets are not lottery tickets align with the principles of consumer protection laws and the expectation of a service-based purchase, rather than a speculative gamble?
If airline tickets are not considered a gamble, why would a passenger's expectation of a seat on a flight be seen as any less negotiable than their expectation of coffee in a cup they pay for?

If airlines are allowed to sell tickets at lower prices or for frequent flyer miles without guaranteeing service, doesn't this essentially make them operate as a form of a lottery system, rather than a reliable mode of transportation?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: Does the airline's incentive structure to prioritize higher-paying passengers over lower-paying ones cause passengers to experience frustration and decreased satisfaction with their travel experience?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports the claim that airlines should prioritize passengers who paid higher fares over those who paid lower fares or received free tickets?
If the airline's primary goal is to maximize profit, would it not be logical to prioritize passengers who pay more, rather than those who pay less or nothing at all?
If airlines are not incentivized by adequate compensation, do they have a legitimate reason to prioritize passengers who pay more over those who pay less?

zuclinator_125.input:
zuclinator: "I know Delta serves peanuts
as I travel to and from Detroit on Delta.
I was really surprised to learn this
as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?
Oh and the two row minimum around a person with a peanut allergy is a joke.
Someone with a peanut allergy is not going to be protected by that!"

cqs.cq: Should airlines be required to inform passengers about the presence of peanuts on flights before they purchase tickets?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that a two-row buffer is an effective safety measure for individuals with peanut allergies?

If Delta requires passengers to be informed about peanuts before they purchase a flight, wouldn't it be equally responsible to disclose the presence of other potential allergens, such as gluten or soy, to passengers with related allergies?
If Delta knows about the peanut policy, why not explicitly inform passengers before booking their flights?

TRUMP_114_1.input:
TRUMP: "we have been told through investigative reporting that he owes about $ 650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks
You learn a lot from financial disclosure
That I can tell you
you should go down and take a look at that
I 'm extremely underleveraged
The report that said $ 650
a lot of friends of mine that know my business
It 's not a lot of money relative to what I had
The buildings that were in question , they said in the same report , which was—actually , it was n't even a bad story , to be honest with you , but the buildings are worth $ 3.9 billion
the $ 650 is n't even on that
it 's not $ 650
It 's much less than that
I could give you a list of banks
I would—if that would help you , I would give you a list of banks
These are very fine institutions
very fine banks
I could do that very quickly
I am very underleveraged
I have a great company
I have a tremendous income
the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way
It 's because it 's about time that this country had somebody running it that has an idea about money
we have $ 20 trillion in debt"

cqs.cq: If the financial report's claim that Trump owes $650 million is significantly understated, does that not raise questions about the true extent of his debt and his ability to make informed decisions about the country's financial management?
Can you provide a detailed breakdown of your financial records to corroborate your claims of being underleveraged and having a $3.9 billion portfolio of buildings?
If a billionaire like Trump can be underleveraged despite owing hundreds of millions, why should ordinary citizens be expected to pay off their much smaller debts?
If Mr. Trump is as financially savvy as he claims, why does he need to be secretive about the specifics of his business dealings and financial obligations?

TRUMP_114_2.input:
TRUMP: "our country 's a mess
it 's one thing to have $ 20 trillion in debt
Our airports are like from a third world country
You land at LaGuardia , you land at Kennedy , you land at LAX , you land at Newark , and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible—you come in from China , you see these incredible airports
we 've become a third world country
our bridges are good
everything 's in great shape
our airports
the worst of all things has happened
We owe $ 20 trillion
we 're a mess
We have n't even started
we 've spent $ 6 trillion in the Middle East
according to a report that I just saw
Whether it 's 6 or 5
 it looks like it 's 6
we could have rebuilt our country twice
it 's really a shame
it 's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem
Our country has tremendous problems
We 're a debtor nation
We 're a serious debtor nation
we have a country that needs new roads , new tunnels , new bridges , new airports , new schools , new hospitals
we don't have the money
it 's been squandered on so many of your ideas"

cqs.cq: If the $6 trillion spent in the Middle East could have been invested in domestic infrastructure, would our country be in the state it is today?
Can you provide evidence from a credible economic or infrastructure expert that supports your claim that our country could have been rebuilt twice with the $20 trillion spent in the Middle East?
If the United States is considered a third-world country in terms of airport infrastructure, would it be accurate to assume that our country's overall infrastructure is on par with those nations?
If the US has the capability to spend $6 trillion in the Middle East, why can't we allocate funds to fix our own infrastructure and address our domestic problems?

TRUMP_121_1.input:
TRUMP: "I do think it's time
it's all words
it's all sound bites
I built an unbelievable company
Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world
real estate assets anywhere in the world
beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places
It's an unbelievable company
on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there
when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation
if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws
you've been there a long time,
I take advantage of the laws of the nation
I'm running a company
My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies
that's what I do
what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me"

cqs.cq: Does using loopholes in the law to build a business empire contribute to a culture of entitlement and a lack of accountability among corporate leaders?
Do you have any credible business or financial experts that support your claim that your business practices are entirely legal and not in violation of any laws?
If a businessman uses loopholes in the law to accumulate wealth, would that be considered a morally justifiable practice?
If you're so concerned about taking advantage of the laws of the nation to benefit yourself, why should others not face consequences for doing the same?

TRUMP_121_2.input:
TRUMP: "I'll give you an example
We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House
if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another
we're opening the Old Post Office
I'm a year ahead of schedule
that's what this country should be doing
We build roads
they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost
We buy products for our military
they come in at costs that are so far above what they were supposed to be
we don't have people that know what they're doing
When we look at the budget, the budget is bad to a large extent
we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy
The Trump International is way under budget
way ahead of schedule
we should be able to do that for our country"

cqs.cq: If Trump's ability to deliver projects like the Trump International under budget and ahead of schedule is due to his expertise in business, then why should the federal government expect different results from its own projects and budgets?

Can you provide a scientific study or credible evidence to support your claim that your management and construction experience at the Trump International is a relevant model for the country's infrastructure projects?

If Trump's ability to manage the budget and construction of his hotel is a benchmark of his competence, would that not indicate that his administration's failures to manage the budget and construction of public projects are a result of incompetence rather than a lack of knowledge?
If the Trump International can be completed under budget and ahead of schedule, why can't the government accomplish similar feats with taxpayer-funded projects?

TRUMP_125_1.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order
If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country
when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's—I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long
I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just—just came in
We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very—I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States
We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in hell
it's so dangerous
You walk down the street, you get shot
In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st
I'm saying, where is this
Is this a war-torn country
What are we doing
we have to stop the violence
In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years
almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president"

cqs.cq: Does the increase in violent crime in cities like Chicago, as Trump suggests, actually cause a breakdown in law and order in the United States?

Can you provide a credible source that supports your claim that Secretary Clinton's stance on law and order is less effective than your own, given the crime rates in Chicago during Barack Obama's presidency?
If the United States is a country plagued by violence, would it not be accurate to describe it as a war-torn country, rather than simply an inner-city problem?

If the conditions in Chicago are so dire that they warrant comparison to a war-torn country, why is that not a more pressing concern for your administration, Mr. Trump, rather than just a law and order issue?

TRUMP_125_2.input:
TRUMP: "almost 4,000 people in Chicago have been killed
 whether or not in a place like Chicago you do stop and frisk, which worked very well, Mayor Giuliani is here, worked very well in New York
It brought the crime rate way down
you take the gun away from criminals that shouldn't be having it
We have gangs roaming the street
in many cases, they're illegally here, illegal immigrants
they have guns
they shoot people
we have to be very strong
we have to be very vigilant
We have to be—we have to know what we're doing
 our police, in many cases, are afraid to do anything
We have to protect our inner cities
African-American communities are being decimated by crime, decimated
No"

cqs.cq: Does the "stop and frisk" policy, which Trump praises, disproportionately target and harm African-American communities, thereby increasing crime rates rather than decreasing them?
Do you have a study that supports the effectiveness of'stop and frisk' policies in reducing crime rates in areas with high concentrations of illegal immigrants?

If stop-and-frisk policies that disproportionately targeted African Americans and Latinos in New York City during Giuliani's tenure were deemed ineffective and even racist, why would implementing a similar policy in Chicago, where it would likely target African Americans, be seen as a solution to the city's high crime rate?
If stop-and-frisk policies were effective in reducing crime in New York City under Giuliani, then why should Chicago, with a higher crime rate, adopt a different approach?

TRUMP_127.input:
TRUMP: "you're wrong
It went before a judge, who was a very against-police judge
It was taken away from her
our mayor, our new mayor, refused to go forward with the case
They would have won an appeal
If you look at it, throughout the country, there are many places where it's allowed"

cqs.cq: If the judge's bias against the police led to the case being taken away from her, do you think that would have had a significant impact on the outcome of the appeal?
Can you provide a scientific source or peer-reviewed study that supports the claim that the case was taken away from the judge and would have won an appeal?
If a judge who is against the police, and a mayor who refuses to pursue a case, are considered impartial, why should we expect a different outcome when a presidential candidate intervenes?
If the case was taken away from a judge who was against the police, and the new mayor refused to move forward, why is that an acceptable outcome when the president is criticising the decision?

TRUMP_129.input:
TRUMP: "the argument is that we have to take the guns away from these people that have them
they are bad people that shouldn't have them
These are felons
These are people that are bad people that shouldn't be
when you have 3,000 shootings in Chicago from January 1st
when you have 4,000 people killed in Chicago by guns, from the beginning of the presidency of Barack Obama, his hometown
you have to have stop-and-frisk
You need more police
You need a better community
relation
You don't have good community relations in Chicago
It's terrible
I have property there
It's terrible what's going on in Chicago
when you look—and Chicago's not the only
you go to Ferguson
you go to so many different places
You need better relationships
I agree with Secretary Clinton on this
You need better relationships between the communities and the police
in some cases, it's not good
you look at Dallas, where the relationships were really studied
the relationships were really a beautiful thing
then five police officers were killed one night very violently
there's some bad things going on
Some really bad things
we need—Lester, we need law and order
we need law and order in the inner cities
the people that are most affected by what's happening are African-American and Hispanic people
it's very unfair to them what our politicians are allowing to happen"

cqs.cq: Does the president's stance on gun control and law enforcement directly contribute to the cycle of violence and mistrust between law enforcement and the communities he claims to want to protect?
Do you have any evidence from reputable studies that supports the claim that stop-and-frisk policies are an effective method to reduce crime and violence in communities?

If a predominantly black neighborhood with a history of crime and distrust of the police is not considered in need of "law and order," why is a predominantly white neighborhood with a history of gun violence not considered in need of similar intervention?
If gun violence disproportionately affects communities of color, then why would stricter gun control laws not be a more targeted solution than stop-and-frisk policies?

TRUMP_13.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton and others , politicians , should have been doing this for years , not right now
we 've created a movement
They should have been doing this for years
What 's happened to our jobs and our country and our economy generally is—look , we owe $ 20 trillion
We can not do it any longer , Lester"

cqs.cq: If politicians have been neglecting their responsibilities for years, why should the current state of the economy be solely blamed on them rather than their predecessors?
Can you provide a credible source that supports the claim that the current economic situation in the United States is solely the fault of politicians, rather than a complex interplay of factors?
If politicians were expected to lead by creating jobs and improving the economy for years, why is it now being criticized as a sudden movement?
If politicians like Secretary Clinton were doing their job properly, why did the country accumulate a $20 trillion debt?

TRUMP_140_1.input:
TRUMP: "a lot of people even within my own party want to give certain rights to people on watch lists and no- fly lists
I agree with you
When a person is on a watch list or a no-fly list
 These are very, very good people
they're protecting the Second Amendment
I have the endorsement of the NRA
I'm very proud of
we have to look very strongly at no-fly lists and watch lists
when people are on there, even if they shouldn't be on there, we'll help them, we'll help them legally, we'll help them get off
I tend to agree with that quite strongly
you were the one that brought up the words super-predator about young black youth
that's a term that I think was a—it's—it's been horribly met
you've apologized for it"

cqs.cq: If people on watch lists and no-fly lists are indeed "very, very good people" as you claim, then why should their rights be restricted in the first place?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support your claim that people on watch and no-fly lists are "very, very good people"?
If individuals can be removed from a no-fly list or watch list without any due process, why would that not be applied to those deemed a "super-predator" and stripped of their rights?

If you support granting rights to individuals on watch lists and no-fly lists despite their potential threat to society, wouldn't that be undermining the purpose of these lists, which is to protect the public from potential harm?

TRUMP_140_2.input:
TRUMP: "it was a terrible thing to say
when it comes to stop-and-frisk, you know, you're talking about takes guns away
I'm talking about taking guns away from gangs and people that use them
I really don't think you disagree with me on this
maybe there's a political reason why you can't say it
in New York City, stop-and-frisk, we had 2,200 murders, and stop-and-frisk brought it down to 500 murders
Five hundred murders is a lot of murders
It's hard to believe, 500 is like supposed to be good
 we went from 2,200 to 500
 it was continued on by Mayor Bloomberg
it was terminated by current mayor
stop-and- frisk had a tremendous impact on the safety of New York City
Tremendous beyond belief"

cqs.cq: Does the reduction in stop-and-frisk policies under the current mayor have a causal relationship with the increase in New York City's murder rate?

Can you provide evidence from a credible study or data source that confirms the significant reduction in murders in New York City from 2,200 to 500, and specifically attribute the decrease to the stop-and-frisk policy?
If a policy that reduced crime by 77% in New York City is deemed effective, why would the same logic not be applied to other cities struggling with high crime rates?

If stop-and-frisk was indeed so effective in reducing crime, why did the current mayor's termination of the policy lead to a subsequent increase in murders, as evidenced by the 2,200 figure reverting?

TRUMP_166.input:
TRUMP: "nobody was pressing it , nobody was caring much about it
I figured you 'd ask the question tonight , of course
nobody was caring much about it
I was the one that got him to produce the birth certificate
I did a good job
Secretary Clinton also fought it
now , everybody in mainstream is going to say , oh , that 's not true
Look , it 's true

you just have to take a look at CNN , the last week , the interview with your former campaign manager
she was involved
just like she ca n't bring back jobs , she ca n't produce"

cqs.cq: Does the media's lack of initial interest in the birth certificate issue cause Trump to be more motivated to pursue it?
Do you have any credible sources to support the claim that you single-handedly got Obama to produce his birth certificate, or is that a claim based on your own opinion?
If Trump's actions were seen as a heroic effort to uncover a hidden truth about Obama's birth certificate, why are his own actions in the same situation seen as deceitful and manipulative?
If you consider yourself a champion of truth and fact-finding, then why did you previously downplay the importance of the birth certificate issue and now criticize others for questioning it?

TRUMP_170.input:
TRUMP: "I say nothing
I was able to get him to produce it
He should have produced it a long time before
When you talk about healing , I think that I 've developed very , very good relationships over the last little while with the African-American community
you can see that
I feel that they really wanted me to come to that conclusion
I did a great job and a great service not only for the country , but even for the president , in getting him to produce his birth certificate"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's ability to obtain the birth certificate actually demonstrate healing relationships with the African-American community or does it merely serve as a validation of his own actions?

Can you provide evidence from a scientific study that supports the claim that you've developed "very, very good relationships" with the African-American community, considering the historical context of racial tensions and your past comments and actions?

If a presidential candidate's ability to produce a birth certificate is seen as a great service to the country, would that not be a double standard if it's used to justify criticizing a community for not producing documentation?

If you're so proud of the progress you've made with the African-American community, why are you still using your supposed success as a way to deflect criticism rather than genuinely addressing the issues at hand?

TRUMP_174_2.input:
TRUMP: "I also notice the very nasty commercials that you do on me in so many different ways , which I do n't do on you
Maybe I 'm trying to save the money
is n't that amazing
I settled that lawsuit with no admission of guilt , but that was a lawsuit brought against many real estate firms , and it 's just one of those things
