In Palm Beach , Florida , tough community , a brilliant community , a wealthy community , probably the wealthiest community there is in the world , I opened a club , and really got great credit for it
No discrimination against African- Americans, against Muslims, against anybody
it's a tremendously successful club
I'm so glad I did it
 I have been given great credit for what I did
'm very, very proud of it
that's the way I feel
That is the true way I feel"

cqs.cq: If the settlement in the real estate lawsuit was not an admission of guilt, then why does it not undermine the credibility of Trump's claim of having done nothing wrong?
Does a reputable source support the claim that the Trump Organization's Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Florida, has no history of discrimination against African Americans or Muslims?
If Trump is proud of opening a club with no discrimination, why does he not extend that same standard to his business practices in other areas, such as those he has been accused of in the past?

Does the fact that you've been given credit for opening a club in a wealthy community justify your claim of being a champion for African Americans and Muslims when you've been criticized for your own discriminatory practices?

TRUMP_183.input:
TRUMP: "I do want to say that I was just endorsed
and more are coming next week
it will be over 200 admirals
many of them here—admirals and generals endorsed me to lead this country
That just happened
many more are coming
I was just endorsed by ICE
They 've never endorsed anybody before on immigration
I was just recently endorsed—16,500 Border Patrol agents
when Secretary Clinton talks about this , I mean , I 'll take the admirals and I 'll take the generals any day over the political hacks that I see that have led our country so brilliantly over the last 10 years with their knowledge
look at the mess that we 're in
As far as the cyber , I agree to parts of what Secretary Clinton said
We should be better than anybody else
perhaps we 're not
I do n't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the DNC"

cqs.cq: Does the endorsement of military personnel by Trump suggest that he has the military's support, or does it instead indicate a strategic attempt to gain their backing for his political campaign?

Can you provide a scientific source that supports the claim that the endorsements from military officials and law enforcement agencies are a reliable indicator of a presidential candidate's leadership abilities?

If admirals and generals endorsing a candidate is a reliable measure of their leadership abilities, why would the endorsements of law enforcement and military officials necessarily make a president more effective?

If endorsements from military officials are a true indicator of a leader's competence, then why have we seen a decline in national security under previous administrations also endorsed by these same officials?

TRUMP_192.input:
TRUMP: "President Obama and Secretary Clinton created a vacuum the way they got out of Iraq
they got out—what , they should n't have been in
once they got in , the way they got out was a disaster
ISIS was formed
she talks about taking them out
She 's been doing it a long time
She 's been trying to take them out for a long time
they would n't have even been formed if they left some troops behind , like 10,000 or maybe something more than that
then you would n't have had them
as I 've been saying for a long time
I think you 'll agree
I said it to you once
had we taken the oil—and we should have taken the oil—ISIS would not have been able to form either
we should have taken the oil
the oil was their primary source of income
now they have the oil all over the place
including the oil—a lot of the oil in Libya
was another one of her disasters"

cqs.cq: If the US had left troops in Iraq, would that have prevented the formation of ISIS?
Can you provide a credible historical source that supports your claim that leaving troops in Iraq would have prevented the formation of ISIS?
If the United States' withdrawal from Iraq was a vacuum that led to the formation of ISIS, would leaving troops in Libya have similarly prevented the rise of terrorist groups there?
If removing American troops from Iraq was a disaster, then wouldn't leaving oil behind have been equally problematic?

TRUMP_202_1.input:
TRUMP: "The secretary said very strongly about working with—we've been working with them for many years, and we have the greatest mess anyone's ever seen
You look at the Middle East, it's a total mess
Under your direction, to a large extent
you look at the Middle East, you started the Iran deal, that's another beauty where you have a country that was ready to fall, I mean, they were doing so badly
They were choking on the sanctions
now they're going to be actually probably a major power at some point pretty soon, the way they're going
when you look at NATO
I was asked on a major show, what do you think of NATO
you have to understand, I'm a businessperson
I did really well
I have common sense. And I said, well, I'll tell you. I haven't given lots of thought to NATO. But two things
the 28 countries of NATO, many of them aren't paying their fair share"

cqs.cq: If the United States had not been involved in the Middle East under your direction, do you think the region would be in a better state than it is now?

Can you provide evidence from your years of experience as a businessperson that demonstrates your ability to effectively lead international relations, given your history of involvement in the Middle East and your comments on NATO?

If a businessperson's success in the business world is considered a qualification for foreign policy expertise, would that not suggest that a businessperson's lack of experience in a particular field is a disqualification for making sweeping changes to that field?
If you claim to have successfully made peace in the Middle East, why have the problems escalated since your involvement?

TRUMP_202_2.input:
TRUMP: "that bothers me
we should be asking—we're defending them, and they should at least be paying us what they're supposed to be paying by treaty and contract
NATO could be obsolete
I was very strong on this, and it was actually covered very accurately in the New York Times, which is unusual for the New York Times, to be honest—but I said, they do not focus on terror
 I was very strong. And I said it numerous times
about four months ago, I read on the front page of the Wall Street Journal that NATO is opening up a major terror division
that's great. And I think we should get
we pay approximately 73 percent of the cost of NATO
It's a lot of money to protect other people. But I'm all for NATO. But I said they have to focus on terror, also
they're going to do that
 I'm not going to get credit for it—but that was largely because of what I was saying and my criticism of NATO
we have to get NATO to go into the Middle East with us, in addition to surrounding nations, and we have to knock the hell out of ISIS, and we have to do it fast
when ISIS formed in this vacuum created by Barack Obama and Secretary Clinton. And believe me, you were the ones that took out the troops. Not only that, you named the day. They couldn't believe it. They sat back probably and said, I can't believe it"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the US pays approximately 73 percent of the cost of NATO contribute to the lack of a unified focus on terror, which is a significant concern for the US?
Can you provide a scientific source that supports your claim that the majority of women are narcissistic sociopaths?

If the US pays approximately 73 percent of the cost of NATO, would that not imply a reciprocal obligation for member nations to provide a similar level of support in other areas, such as military operations in the Middle East?
If we are truly concerned about the financial burden of NATO, shouldn't we reconsider our commitment to the alliance if its primary focus is not aligned with our own national security interests?

TRUMP_222.input:
TRUMP: "I have much better judgment than she does
There 's no question about that
I also have a much better temperament than she has
she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on an advertising
they get Madison Avenue into a room
they put names
temperament , let 's go after
my strongest asset , maybe by far , is my temperament
I have a winning temperament
I know how to win
She does not have a
Wrong
there 's a person with a temperament that 's got a problem
The AFL-CIO the other day , behind the blue screen , I do n't know who you were talking to , Secretary Clinton , but you were totally out of control
 I do n't know who you were talking to"

cqs.cq: Does having a "winning temperament" actually correlate with effective leadership?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that a "winning temperament" is a key factor in a presidential candidate's success?
If a businessman with a history of being "out of control" can be considered a strong asset, why is a politician with a similar temperament considered unfit for office?
If Trump's temperament is his strongest asset, then why is it that many of his critics describe him as having a volatile and unpredictable temperament?

TRUMP_236.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not an accurate one at all
It 's not an accurate one
I just want to give a lot of things
just to respond
I agree with her on one thing
The single greatest problem the world has is nuclear armament , nuclear weapons
not global warming
like you think
your—your president thinks
Nuclear is the single greatest threat
Just to go down the list , we defend Japan , we defend Germany , we defend South Korea , we defend Saudi Arabia , we defend countries
They do not pay us
they should be paying us
we are providing tremendous service
we 're losing a fortune
we 're losing
we lose on everything
All I said , that it 's very possible that if they do n't pay a fair share
this is n't 40 years ago where we could do what we 're doing
if they do n't pay a fair share
We ca n't defend Japan , a behemoth , selling us cars by the million"

cqs.cq: If a country relies heavily on the United States for defense but refuses to pay a fair share, would that lead to the United States reconsidering its defense commitments to that country?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that a 'fair share' of military protection from the United States is equivalent to 'paying us' or can be quantified in monetary terms?
If the United States protects countries like Japan and Saudi Arabia, which do not contribute financially, why should it be expected that other nations would pay the United States for its defense?
If nuclear armament is the single greatest problem, then why are we prioritizing defense spending on countries that don't contribute financially?

TRUMP_240_1.input:
TRUMP: "for what Secretary Clinton was saying about nuclear with Russia , she 's very cavalier in the way she talks about various countries
Russia has been expanding their
they have a much newer capability than we do
We have not been updating from the new standpoint
I looked the other night
I was seeing B-52s
they 're old enough that your father , your grandfather could be flying them
we are not keeping up with other countries
 I would like everybody to end it
just get rid of it
I would certainly not do first strike
once the nuclear alternative happens , it 's over
At the same time , we have to be prepared
I ca n't take anything off the table
you look at some of these countries , you look at North Korea , we 're doing nothing there
China should solve that problem for us
China should go into North Korea
China is totally powerful as it relates to North Korea"

cqs.cq: If the US is not keeping up with Russia's nuclear capabilities, as you've stated, why do you believe the US would be safe from Russia's nuclear threat?
Do you have any credible sources to back up the claim that Russia has a more advanced nuclear capability than the United States?
If the US is justified in pressuring China to handle North Korea's nuclear threats, why would it not be justifiable for the US to intervene in Russia's military actions?
If the United States is struggling to keep up with Russia's nuclear capabilities, shouldn't we focus on upgrading our own arsenal rather than criticizing others?

CL_8.input:
CL: "Doesn’t it worry you at all that you're taking advantage of people when they are really in no position to negotiate?
They have absolutely very little choice except to take the terms that are being offered to them"

cqs.cq: Does taking advantage of people in a vulnerable position ultimately cause them to be exploited, leading to long-term negative effects on their financial and emotional well-being?
Do you have any research or data to support your claim that people in vulnerable positions are more likely to negotiate better terms when they have limited options?
If an employer taking advantage of a desperate employee is seen as morally reprehensible, why wouldn't a system that exploits desperate people for their labor be considered equally problematic?
If you're concerned about exploiting vulnerable individuals, then why do you support a policy that relies on desperate people accepting unfavorable terms?

MT_14.input:
MT: "We have indeed required those products to have very large warnings on them, telling people about their salt and fat content
And we don’t allow them to say things which are misleading
We don’t allow fatty products to say they're healthy
I've got in front of me a letter from a credit card company
There are two figures on this letter which really stand out: 0% per annum new balance transfers, 0% per annum new money transfers
Now, underneath that, in small print, it becomes absolutely clear that you’ll be paying all sorts of charges
And then very, very quickly you’ll be lured into paying a very large charge
Do you think it’s responsible to encourage people to mis-read something like that?
I’ve got all the information there in front of me
Why is that irresponsible?"

cqs.cq: Does allowing credit card companies to advertise low introductory interest rates in large print and hidden fees in small print cause consumers to misread the true costs of their credit card agreements?

Do you believe that hiding behind transparency disclosures is sufficient to absolve financial institutions from responsibility for misleading consumers with seemingly attractive but ultimately deceptive promotions?

If we deem it deceptive to obscure fine print on a credit card statement, why is it not considered deceptive to obscure the true cost of a food product by labeling it as "healthy" when it's actually high in salt and fat?

If we're holding companies accountable for misleading consumers through fine print, shouldn't we also hold politicians accountable for hiding information behind "small print" and "fine print" in their policies and promises?

MT_45.input:
MT: "Claire’s absolutely right about that
But then the problem is that that form of capitalism wasn’t generating sufficient surpluses
And so therefore where did the money flow
It didn’t flow into those industrial activities
 because in the developed world that wasn’t making enough money"

cqs.cq: If the industrial activities aren't generating sufficient surpluses to drive economic growth, then what alternative sectors or investments would be capable of filling this economic gap?
Can you provide a credible economic theory or study that supports the claim that capitalism in the developed world was not generating sufficient surpluses?

If the flow of money into industrial activities in the developed world is the key to generating sufficient surpluses, why wouldn't a similar flow of money into marginalized communities be a more effective strategy for stimulating economic growth?
If capitalism is not generating sufficient surpluses, then why are we placing so much emphasis on its ability to drive economic growth?

ND_23.input:
ND: " I think in the current situation that both savers and borrowers, if you're talking about individual people, are doing extremely badly
many people are unable to make ends meet and are having to take debt out at huge levels of interest
On the other hand, savers are earning nothing in interest
And what this needs is not simply us putting moral blame on one side or the other
but actually putting moral blame on a set of economic policies and political decisions that have led to credit liberalisation."

cqs.cq: Do economic policies and political decisions that promote credit liberalization cause individuals to accumulate debt, exacerbating financial struggles?

Do you have any empirical evidence from credible economic sources that supports the claim that current economic policies and political decisions are primarily responsible for the struggles of savers and borrowers?
If we view economic policies as a system of racial oppression, why wouldn't we hold those policies accountable for the suffering of all individuals, regardless of their ability to save or borrow?
If savers are suffering due to low interest rates, does that justify the moral blame on economic policies and political decisions rather than individuals making irresponsible borrowing decisions?

CF_62.input:
CF: "RS: Provide that for our young people
 These are young adults; you’re kind of treating them as though they’re passive recipients of something.
 And I suppose that’s my concern; how do we encourage the young?
It’s not beyond the imagination to imagine the young might get up and go and do something about this, other than kind of sit and wait to be handed something.
Now you’re saying “Provide that for our young people”, and in a way that’s where I’m going."

cqs.cq: Will providing resources for young people lead them to become passive recipients rather than active agents of change?

Do you have any evidence from scientific research that supports the claim that young adults are typically passive recipients of information rather than active participants in seeking knowledge and empowerment?
If the young people are treated as active agents rather than passive recipients, why wouldn't they be held accountable for creating their own opportunities rather than relying on being handed them?
Are you implying that the young people are incapable of taking initiative or responsibility for their own actions and futures?

JW_35.input:
JW: "JW has got a rather nuanced view, that the way they're mis-used can have morally damaging consequences
Well, debt is morally neutral in the sense that it can be good to be in debt
 Sometimes it’s a good idea, and sometimes it’s a bad idea
And so I think there’s been broad agreement about that in the discussion so far
The question is why is there too much debt?
 Why are people taking on too much debt?
 this one is the elaboration of the previous question Now,
a lot of people come up with rather glib moral answers: somehow bankers want them to get into excessive debt
 which is a very peculiar idea, when you think that it’s the bankers who aren’t going to get repaid. So it’s a very odd idea
there’s too much debt for the same reason that there are too many unmarried mothers, and for the same reason that you get an overproduction of sheep."

cqs.cq: If the moral neutrality of debt leads to its misuse, what role do societal and economic factors play in causing people to take on excessive debt?
Can you provide a scientific study or credible source to support your claim that the reasons for excessive debt are as simplistic as blaming bankers?
If bankers are not typically the ones who suffer the consequences of excessive debt, why are they not held accountable for the moral damage caused by their lending practices?
If debt is morally neutral and sometimes beneficial, then why do you consider excessive debt morally damaging?

CLINTON_1_1.input:
CLINTON: "The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we 'll build together
Today is my granddaughter 's second birthday
I think about this a lot
we have to build an economy that works for everyone , not just those at the top
we need new jobs , good jobs , with rising incomes
I want us to invest in you
I want us to invest in your future
jobs in infrastructure , in advanced manufacturing , innovation and technology , clean , renewable energy , and small business
most of the new jobs will come from small business
We also have to make the economy fairer
That starts with raising the national minimum wage and also guarantee , finally , equal pay for women 's work
I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing"

cqs.cq: If the economy is built to work only for those at the top, will the future we build together truly benefit everyone, or will it widen the gap between the wealthy and the working class?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that raising the national minimum wage and guaranteeing equal pay for women's work will create a fairer economy?

If investing in a country's economy is likened to investing in a family's future, why would the benefits of such investments not be extended to all families, regardless of their socio-economic status?
If we invest in everyone's future as you claim, why not prioritize the most vulnerable and those who have been left behind, rather than just focusing on creating new jobs for the privileged few?

TRUMP_99.input:
TRUMP: "I will release them as soon as the audit
I 've been under audit almost for 15 years
I know a lot of wealthy people that have never been audited
I said , do you get audited
do you get audited
I get audited almost every year
in a way , I should be complaining
I 'm not even complaining
I do n't mind it
It 's almost become a way of life
I get audited by the IRS
But other people don't
We have a situation in this country that has to be taken care of
I will release my tax returns—against my lawyer 's wishes—when she releases her 33,000 e-mails that have been deleted
As soon as she releases them , I will release
I will release my tax returns
that 's against—my lawyers
they say , `` Do n't do it . '' I will tell you this
No—in fact , watching shows , they 're reading the papers
Almost every lawyer says , you do n't release your returns until the audit 's complete
When the audit 's complete , I 'll do it
I would go against them if she releases her e-mails"

cqs.cq: If he gets audited almost every year, why does he claim that releasing his tax returns would be against his lawyer's wishes?

Can you provide evidence from a credible audit or tax expert that suggests releasing tax returns before an audit is complete is standard practice, despite your claim that you're doing it against your lawyer's wishes?
If Trump is willing to defy his lawyer's advice to wait until the audit is complete to release his tax returns, why is he not releasing his tax returns as soon as the audit is finished?

If you claim to be transparent about your tax affairs, why do you refuse to release your tax returns until after the audit is complete, a process that could take years, unlike others who release their returns promptly?

TRUMP_174_1.input:
TRUMP: "I would love to respond
I got to watch in preparing for this some of your debates against Barack Obama
You treated him with terrible disrespect
I watched the way you talk now about how lovely everything is and how wonderful you are
It does n't work that way
You were after him
you were trying to—you even sent out or your campaign sent out pictures of him in a certain garb , very famous pictures
I do n't think you can deny that
just last week , your campaign manager said it was true
when you tried to act holier than thou , it really does n't work
as far as the lawsuit , yes , when I was very young , I went into my father 's company , had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens , and we , along with many , many other companies throughout the country—it was a federal lawsuit—were sued
We settled the suit with zero—with no admission of guilt
It was very easy to do
I notice you bring that up a lot"

cqs.cq: If the manner in which you treated Barack Obama during debates is a reflection of how you would interact with world leaders, does that demonstrate a propensity for respectful international diplomacy?
Can you provide a scientific study or credible source that supports the claim that you "were after" Barack Obama during the debates?
If Trump's own family business was sued and settled a federal lawsuit without admitting guilt, why would he imply that Biden is guilty of something just because he was sued?
If you're so confident in your moral superiority, how can you justify your past attempts to demonize a political opponent based on his faith?

TRUMP_112.input:
TRUMP: "That was more than a mistake
That was done purposely
That was not a mistake
When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment , taking the Fifth so they 're not prosecuted
when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth
it 's disgraceful
this country thinks it's—really thinks it 's disgraceful , also
As far as my tax returns , you do n't learn that much from tax returns"

cqs.cq: If having a staff member take the Fifth Amendment and a server involved in the illegal setup also taking the Fifth Amendment is considered disgraceful, does it justify questioning or investigating a president's tax returns?
Can you provide a credible source that supports your claim that having staff take the Fifth Amendment is not a red flag for obstruction of justice?
If intentionally hiding information and taking the Fifth Amendment is considered a serious offense, why should intentionally evading tax payments not be viewed as equally severe?
If you're willing to criticize others for hiding information, why are you not taking the same stance on your own tax returns?

CLINTON_244_1.input:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them
It is essential that America 's word be good
I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good
It 's also important that we look at the entire global situation
There 's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran
personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.cq: If a president's words have significant influence on international relations, then why should the actions of a president be considered less impactful than their rhetoric?
Do you have a specific example of a time when you, as President, honored a mutual defense treaty with another country?
If a president's words are as crucial as you claim, then would your past words and actions be considered as trustworthy as you are portraying them to be?
If our word is good, then why have our past actions and interventions in countries like Iraq and Libya been so inconsistent with our rhetoric?
